												Tapping into that extraordinarily familiar ground that Clash of Clans first revolutionized, Battle Islands is a briefly entertaining if slow-burning freemium strategy game. It’s a little too familiar to truly warrant much excitement but those keen for a World War 2 themed title will find more enjoyment.Set in 1942, players control a platoon of soldiers as they attempt to establish bases on various tropical islands in the South Pacific. While the theme is slightly different from the norm, the gameplay remains much the same.A brief tutorial guides one through the basics, which mostly relate to placing buildings and training troops. A barrier keeps players protected from enemy attack for a few days in order to give them a chance to be more established, but this is easily circumvented by the bloodthirsty. Once the tutorial is out of the way, structure is offered through a series of challenges that can be completed with the bonus being that they offer up gold bricks.Gold bricks are essential here given that they’re the premium currency that affects how quickly projects are completed, among other things. While Battle Islands might seem initially generous with the gold bricks, they vanish quite quickly – leaving one quite restricted due to the plethora of timers.Waiting around for various tasks to complete will be a regular part of one’s sessions with Battle Islands. It’s really quite slow going. Competing with opposing players is briefly fun, but it’s nothing new for the genre and plays it very safe.It’s the theme that makes Battle Islands slightly more noticeable, with the World War 2 theme often proving more endearing than something fantastical. That’s sufficient for a brief play session but I’d be surprised if anyone found the game truly gripping for any length of time. It’s not that it does anything particularly badly, it’s just all too familiar.Graphics / Sound Rating: ★★★½☆Gameplay Rating: ★★½☆☆Playtime Rating: ★★½☆☆Replay Value Rating: ★★★☆☆Overall Rating: ★★★☆☆

												The "gameplay" mostly consists of waiting. This wouldn't be so bad if there weren't two annoying things:You can be attacked. I don't know what happens if you lose but at least you will lose resources and probably defensive troops.You need to check back too often. If it was designed as a game where you check back once or twice a day, it would be okay to mostly wait. Unfortunately in the early stages resources fill too fast in production buildings, and things get expensive quickly, so you need to check back every few hours to not waste resources, especially in the oil rig that produces 1300 and holds 2500 at level 2 on which you'll be for a few days.Obviously I can't say how the late game will play out, but currently I see it as a way to get achievements easily every few days, instead of a real game. If you don't go for achievements, you will want to avoid this. But ok, below is a short review.What is Battle Islands?Battle Islands is a F2P-style base builder in isometric perspective. It is completely controlled with the mouse. The graphics are  as seen in the screenshots on the store page. The sound is nice but in style with the game heroic and military. You build a base on an island, or later several islands of which your first one always is the biggest, so the base won't grow too much. There also are water buildings, adding a bit to the depth. The game has PvP which can be turned off only for a short time with real money currency (gold bars) paid items. Gold bars are also acquired for achievements and very few sometimes at a daily spin. This will allow you to realistically get three buildings or upgrades built at the same time later, however they will take several days or maybe even longer to upgrade. You can promote units to make them stronger, the cost increase for them that comes with it won't matter much.There is a campaign against the AI, consisting of 30 missions. Lost units won't be regained, but also surviving units won't return to your base, forcing you to rebuild every unit you send. Units take a moderate time to produce, I'm not sure if they take longer later.The best thing about the game is that you get achievements essentially for doing nothing but waiting and upgrading your base... if you're not robbed in PvP...Producing ingame resources goes fast, but later upgrades cost a ton of resources, accumulating to already several days of production even with fully upgraded buildings. For that reason, it might be best to upgrade the command bunker and resource productions and possibly defenses first and invest not much in offensive, but this would need testing.Recommended: Only for achievement hunters

												In Sum: A dull Facebook game that is unbearably slow without microtransactions, and suffers from apparent controversy by the dev.  It just isn't fun.  0/5-----This is basically a Facebook game on Steam.  And it brings with it the failings of a Facebook game.The biggest issue in design, as far as I'm concerned, is the time.  This is not a game that you sit down and play.  You do an action, then have to wait hours, sometimes, days, for it to happen.  The game uses real time for this.  Games such as this are not designed for fun or competition.  They are made for compulsion.  And that is the psychological strategy of this game.  You can build or upgrade something and wait from 10 minutes to 24 hours (maybe longer), or you can whip out the credit card and do it instantly.  The design of the game isn't necessarily "pay-to-win", but rather to make not paying so annoying and frustrating, that you pay repeatedly just to find the enjoyable game in here.  Meanwhile, those who do pay can progress essentially without limits, as every aspect of the game can be instant with purchasing.  To be fair, it is possible to play this game for free.  If you only play sporadically and are willing to progress painfully slow. I realize this is common practice in mobile games, but it is out of place on Steam.  Coming from a number of strategy games before playing this, I found the soldier's actions to be irritating to watch, due to the stupidity.  Sometimes you see them actually do something intelligent, like stopping just outside of howitzer range but in general, attacking troops will run into danger, then proceed to attack buildings while being fired on.  They also will try to group together in a clump, which makes them easily killed as a group.  Due to the slow progression, it is probable that defenses will develop faster than attack power, which causes a sudden bottleneck in progress...unless the credit card comes out.  Overall after playing a few hours, I have to say, I'm not having fun.  I don't feel this was a particular good waste of my time.  I don't feel I have much in the way of positive feedback, because the issue is ultimately the design of the game.  It is truly a casual game in every sense, that not only is it meant for people who only check in every so often, but it requires you to approach it casually.  As for the game, it's not broken, it's just not fun.I have some concerns as well, about the developer's reputed actions on the community hub.  Apparently, criticisms about the game are being deleted, critics of the game are being banned, and recently a dubious set of community rules was posted on the forum superceding Steam's rules that, along with reasonable prohibitions (which were already against Steam's rules), states that "spreading misinformation" will result in a ban.  This could reasonably be construed as any information contrary to the developer's statements, which would include criticism.  Adding this clause lends credence to the reputation this game has been developing.

												This game is overall a fun experience if one is willing to put the time and effort in. Progress will be very slow, and saving up resources is difficult because of the constant threat of attack. It is very similar to Clash of Clans, but in my personal opinion has a more logical setting. There are several negative things about this game, however. As far as I know, there is no form of a group attack, and very little reason to be in an alliance. Attacking other islands is difficult. Not because the controls are bad or anything like that, but simply because you have 20 seconds to plan your attack, and then 2 minutes to finish it. This is not nearly enough time to plan a well-executed attack, and will usually result either in defeat or a disheveled victory. Also, there is LITTLE POINT IN BUYING CAMO. It goes away as soon as you attack someone else and so should only be bought if you want to sit there and do nothing. Nevertheless, the gameplay, and unlockable items are fun and there is definitely some strategy involved, which is why I would recommend this game.

If that's not bad enough; as soon as I save up 1,000,000 someone at level 120 with 2800 dog tags will come and take half.  Because they take more than I can possibly earn in battle, I will never be able to upgrade beyond my current state. Posted: November 12, 2014
												This game is a lot of fun. It can be a little challenging (ok, a lot) with all the bully commanders and tyrants out there pummeling your humble defenses and farming away your hard earned crates. But, that's one of the reasons to like the game - the challenge and strategy required to preserve your stockpile long enough to advance to the next level and achievement. It can be a little disturbing when your supplies get taken away, especially just prior to the implementation of upgrading your units and defenses. I'd whine and cry a little more if I wasn't guilty of doing that to others myself - after all, it's WAR! And even the mighty lion and the fastest cheetah go for the weakest prey. Why fight someone your own size to risk great loss when you can pound a lesser army and take all the booty you want. Ever hear of Sun Tzu? It's a great game, loads fast, functional and free to play, The developers are happy to sell you gold at a fairly reasonable cost which can be used to purchase massive amounts of supplies. . .but where's the fun it that? Only a weak-minded, cowardly, punk-axx, spend-thrift little sissy/bully would need to do that. Also, it can be very helpful if you have the availability to log on for a couple minutes about every hour or so, but you can also go days and weeks without doing so and still find yourself in pretty good shape since no one can actually permanently destroy your base - you just lose crates and dog tags. Give it a try, it's cool. And, you can also draw really cool pictures of the islands and units in a makeshift birthday card to your girlfriend when you forget about her, add a quick rhyme and a clever poem about your gameplay and how it in no way compares to all her talent and beauty, and then she'll love you even more and appreciate all your efforts in the game while she's making dinner and cleaning up around the house. (She's smacking me in the back of the head right now - I gotta go) Play the game.

												Battle Islands is alot like Clash of Clans in many aspects.  The game is blatantly "pay to win" by nature, while not completely limiting free players, it gives paying players a large advantage when it comes to base building and unit production. I dont automatically discount Battle Islands because of these facts though, as they show more of the nature of the mobile and social gaming industry than they display how poor the game is. I think Battle Islands is a decent game on the mobile/ social standard but it does leave much to be desired when it comes to a PC game. Overall I hope mobile and social gaming will hit a point where the start to realize you can have a good game without making pay to win shortcuts, but I doubt this will happen if people still make there crappy in game purchases. So in the end all I can say is give Battle Islands a try, just try not to pay real money for anything.

												Many say that this game is another money grabber a pay to win game & yes they are correct in saying that to a degree BUT they only get your money if you choose to give it to them & if you enjoy the game for what it is then you are basically not paying to win but playing to enjoy. ----- A Few Points -----#1: The game has been labeled as a f2p so you choose weather or not to install & play it, you don't have a loaded gun against your head that's forcing you to do so, either play it or not its simple.#2: I admit i have payed alittle of my own money to get an extra engineer & maybe a few quick upgrades but AGAIN thats players choice not the devs threatening your life if you dont,but you do get a few free gold (microtransaction currency) by completing some in-game achievements which is nice.#3: This game has its moments & i have no complaints with it being a f2p but mere suggestions on what may need improving, yes it has its in-game issues for a few players and they can be very upsetting but thats because its a video game not a painting by Leonardoda vinci (refering to it being perfect :p)#4: This is a browser style kind of game that you progress through with the aid of real time, for example: The command bunker level  3 upgrade (level 3 unlocks a nice selection of units) will take 24hours in real time to complete, yes its quite a wait but when you leave the game to do its work and go off to play something else it has the next stage ready for you to use when/if you return which to be honest i like but could do with a slight tweek here and there.----- Final Verdict -----Battle Islands is a very fun small f2p game that has its moments and can be enjoyed by anyone, it may be a bit of a waiting game (literally) but can be played WITHOUT any microtransactions if one chooses.Overall Score 8/10Hope my little rant has helped in some way :D''See you on the battlefield'' (or not)

												The game starts off and is alot of fun! You construct and maintain your islands and army, you raid other players bases, and run through the campaign, which at some points, others up a bit of a challenge. Seems like a blast right? IT IS! But then reality sets in. You get build times of 10 days just so you can hold more resources to wait another 10 days to spend. Training times for troops aren't too bad at first, 20 second, 45 second, but then you have some that are an hour, which kills the whole 'quick retraining' thing. I see what the Devs want, which is for you to spend money to build stuff quicker, but the amount of money you would have to spend to make any difference at all is absolutely ridiculous.Over all, I feel like it is a good game, but due to the huge wait times and extreme depending on spending cash, I would not recommend this game.

												If you never played this game before you will probably dislike it like I did when I first started.  I didn't want to quit playing it on the first try so I played it for 2 or 3 days to see if it would hold my attention. I now play it on the IPAD, PC and PS4 on the daily basis because it's very entertaining once you understand the mechanics.In short, you have to build your military might by attacking online rivals, completing battle campaigns, upgrading your factories, oil rigs and defending your resources from invasion.  The players  whom have the best offensive and defensive strategy rise quickly via upgrades, promotions and joint battle operations.If you don't like waiting you have the option to buy gold bricks which allow you to avoid long waiting periods associated with crafting your offensive and defensive measures in order to engage in more intense battles. Gold is rewarded to all players after their meter reaches 100% and they move on to the next level so this is completely optional.The game gets better as you progress and build a stronger military to handle both offensive and defensive measures. Eventually you will want to form an online alliance or create your own. This will allow you to team up against stronger rivals whom will grant you many more rewards if you are successful on the battlefield.There are some frustrating issues with the games like tanks ignoring enemy fire even though you send in 5 tanks to handle business in the general area. Another issue is bunker soldiers shooting through buildings and destroying tanks and soldiers that are clearly at a safe distance behind a fortified wall ect .. The artificial intelligence could be a bit better but overall it's still a fun game to play overtime.

												Ten-hut! This is Battle Islands, a ww2 based "free-to-play" game, where the player will have his/her own island fortress, it's basically a singleplayer strategy game online, and with singleplayer I mean that you can't see your friends/enemies play but you can still fight them when they're offline. In Battle Islands the player have to focus a lot on both defense and how to attack the enemies. You can have as follows: Land units i.e. soldiers, jeeps and tanks.Naval units i.e. gunboats, warships and submarines.Air units i.e. fighters, bombers and torpedo bombers.In this game you'll be using supplies and gold as a currency. Supplies is used for the most e.g. training units fortifying structures, upgrade/promote units and structures and also buy stuff. Gold can be used to buy supplies and camouflage (camouflage is used to be hidden from other players so they can't attack you). The player can also buy gold with real money if necessary, but it's not needed since you eventually earn gold throughout the game.Battle Islands is a game that craves a lot of patience, so you better find yourself something else to keep you preoccupied while waiting, unless you buy gold to boost the gameplay. Your armies can be used to both attack other bases, as well as defend you own. You can also build different structures, like factories, supply depots and rigs to get extra supplies from. Barracks, ship yards and hangars to get your attack troops from. The basic defense units comes from the camp, harbor and airfield. You will also be using machinegunners, howitzers, anti-air guns and sea forts to defend your base.In battles against players you'll take and lose dogtags, dogtags tells how experienced you are in battles against other players, and if you've been attacked a lot.There is a campaign of 30 levels where you can loot some supplies. If you're a beginner I would recommend to fight the campaign first, but you won't earn any tags from it.In Battle Islands you'll spend a lot of time on upgrading your stuff, blasting other players bases and move around structures to create a stable defense.I think this game is simply fun,challenging and a bit frustrating. But this game still has some minor bugs, for some reason the one you chat with can't see some words you type, it's like some weird censorship e.g. if you type "attack" you'll see it but other players will not, and I really mean that "attack" is censored in the chat. There is another weird glitch: In some random occasions the jeep in the command bunker or barrack displays a destroyed look.I would recommend this fun game to anyone with patience and taste for simplicity.Battle Islands is currently available for iPad/iPhone/iPod, any android device,PC and now PS4. Did I miss anything?Dismissed!.

												NOTE: This game is Free to Play, as a result of that fact, take this review and all others with a grain of salt as you can basically play it yourself, and I encourage you to, so you can see with your own eyes. Infact, do just that instead of reading this review so your opinion will not be weighted by my own.So this game is basically Boom Beach in a lower quality. In the very beginning, you are greeted with an on-rails tutorial segment that everyone that isn't Supercell does with their Clash-like or Boom Beahc ripoffs... usually.As a note, this game will be treating it as just that; a boom beach clone.So after playing it some more after that point, I've found that you can add segments onto your island, though I feel this limits defensive possibilities, you can't cancel upgrades, change resolution, make the game fullscreen or change hte UI screen size, and most of all... units that deploy have no collision with the environment's rocks, and with eachother, which doesn't make much sense since there's always multiple entry points to any base.Looking at the unit list, there is definitely alot to be unlocked and aimed for, and due to the fact that nothing requires a level 10 or higher HQ (It's called a Command Bunker, but bear with me.), I'll assume hte level cap is or may be Level 10, even if temporarily. Also alongside units are even more buildings to get, most of which are gained before HQ 7, which also might be the level cap right now or for all time.The game at first has one resources; Supplies, which I assume you get more resource types later on.I didn't play for long since... Well in my honest opinion, boom Beach jsut leaves a better impression.I would suggest that the game's unit collision (while deploying, when deployed I don't care) is adjusted to be there, at least with the environment as it just looks bad. I also would at some point put some more work into the grapical design, it looks pretty basic for what (i think) is a completed product.I also would strongly advise allowing players to skip the tutorial.Altogether, the game left a fairly sour first impression with me, so I will rate it...4/10. The game does seem to have some good, unique-ish elements like island expanding which is slightly cusomizable, but it needs work before I personally would call it passable by any means.It's free to play, so maybe you'll enjoy it more, just get past the tutorial and act as if you just started playing.
